com.noctarius.tengi.core.model

Class Packet

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.noctarius.tengi.core.model.Packet
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Marshallable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Handshake

    public class Packet
extends Object
implements Marshallable

    The Packet class is a convenient way to design network packets which can either be used directly or by subclassing it.

       Packet packet = new Packet("login");
   packet.setValue("username", "myUserName");
   packet.setValue("password", hash("myPassword"));
   packet.setValue("metadata", "some dynamic value");
   connection.writeObject(packet);

    By default all properties, defined with setValue(String, Object), are serialized as objects which can be quiet inefficient, by subclassing the Packet instance, serialization for known properties might be optimized. That way fixed properties and dynamic properties can be combined.

       @TypeId(12345)
   public class LoginPacket extends Packet {
     private String username;
     private String password;

     public LoginPacket() {
       super("LoginPacket");
     }

     public void setUsername(String username) {
       notNull("username", username);
       this.username = username;
     }
     public String getUsername() { return username; }

     public void setPassword(String password) {
       notNull("password", password);
       this.password = password;
     }
     public String getPassword() { return password; }

     protected void marshall0(Encoder encoder, Protocol protocol) {
       encoder.writeString(username);
       encoder.writeString(password);
     }

     protected void unmarshall0(Decoder decoder, Protocol protocol) {
       username = decoder.readString();
       password = decoder.readString();
     }
   }

   LoginPacket packet = new LoginPacket();
   packet.setUsername("myUserName");
   packet.setPassword(hash("myPassword"));
   packet.setValue("metadata", "some dynamic value");
   connection.writeObject(packet);

    Packet subclasses need to register their own typeid when using the default protocol to be uniquely identified. This can either be achieved by annotating the class with TypeId or by implementing Identifiable interface. A special Marshaller is also an option to completely adopt the default serialization but it is not recommended to use a Packet subclass in this case.

    For more information on custom serialization please see Encoder, Decoder and Protocol.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Packet

        public Packet(String packetName)
        Creates a new Packet instance with the given packet name. The name is not used internally but can be used by user-code to distinguish different logic based on its given name.
        Parameters:
        packetName - the given name of the packet to distinguish different types of packets

    • Method Detail

      • setValue

        public <V> void setValue(String key,
                         V value)
        Assigns a key to a value. The value must be a of a serializable type, otherwise serialization will fail with an exception while sending the packet. Both key and value must be non-null, otherwise a NullPointerException is thrown. If called with an already existing key, any previously assigned value to the key will be overridden.
        Type Parameters:
        V - the type of the value
        Parameters:
        key - the key to assign the value to
        value - the assigned value
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - whenever key or value are null

      • getValue

        public <V> V getValue(String key)

        Retrieves a value from the internal value set assigned to the given key. If the key doesn't have an assigned value null is returned. The given key must be non-null, otherwise a NullPointerException is thrown.

        The value is implicitly casted to the type of the assignment and might throw a ClassCastException if the retrieve value and the assignment type are not assignable to each other.

        Type Parameters:
        V - the implicit type of the value
        Parameters:
        key - the key to retrieve its assigned value
        Returns:
        the assigned value, if exists, otherwise null
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - whenever key is null
        ClassCastException - whenever the returned value is not assignment compatible to the assignment type

      • getPacketName

        public String getPacketName()
        Returns the packet's name which was given while creating the packet.
        Returns:
        the packet's name

        public final void marshall(Encoder encoder,
                           Protocol protocol)
                    throws Exception
        Description copied from interface: Marshallable
        This method implements logic to marshall (serialize) this object into a stream of bytes using the given Encoder. The given Protocol instance might be used to build complex stream graphs.
        Specified by:
        marshall in interface Marshallable
        Parameters:
        encoder - the Encoder to write to
        protocol - the Protocol instance for additional protocol complexity
        Throws:
        Exception - whenever an unexpected situation occurs while marshalling
